context: In 1979, <a0_0><a0_1><b5_0>the <a0_2>Soviet Union<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> deployed its 40th Army into Afghanistan, attempting to suppress <a1_0><a1_1><b6_0>an <a1_2>Islamic rebellion<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_0/> against an allied Marxist regime<a1_1/> in the Afghan Civil War. The conflict, pitting indigenous impoverished Muslims (mujahideen) against an anti-religious superpower, galvanized thousands of Muslims around the world to <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b7_0>send aid and sometimes to go themselves to fight for their faith<b7_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>. Leading this pan-Islamic effort was Palestinian sheikh Abdullah Yusuf Azzam. While the military effectiveness of these "Afghan Arabs" was <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b8_0>marginal<b8_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>, an estimated <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><b9_0>16,000 to 35,000<b9_0/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/> Muslim volunteers came from around the world came to fight in Afghanistan.
